title: 107_s39
content: The Public Safety Officer Medal of Valor Act of 2001 authorizes the President to award a Medal of Valor to public safety officers for extraordinary acts of valor. The Medal of Valor is the highest national award for valor by a public safety officer. The Medal of Valor Review Board, composed of 11 members with expertise in public safety, is established to conduct business in accordance with the Act. Members are appointed by Senate and House leaders. The Medal of Valor Review Board consists of 11 members appointed by Senate and House leaders, the President, and the House of Representatives. Board members serve a 4-year term and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairman is elected by the Board members and meetings must be held within 90 days of the last member's appointment. The Medal of Valor Review Board consists of 11 members appointed by Senate and House leaders, the President, and the House of Representatives. The Board meets at the call of the Chairman not less than twice a year. A majority of members constitute a quorum for business, and the Board selects Medal of Valor recipients from received applications. The Medal of Valor Review Board recommends recipients for the Medal of Valor to the Attorney General, with a limit of 5 recipients per year. The Board may hold hearings and set an annual timetable for its duties. Witnesses appearing before the Board may receive fees as per section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. The Board may obtain necessary information from Federal agencies and keep it confidential to avoid compromising ongoing investigations or violating confidentiality laws. SEC. 4. BOARD PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Board members are compensated at a rate equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Members who are officers or employees of the government serve without additional compensation. They are also allowed travel expenses while performing duties for the Board. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. Defines "public safety officer" and "State." SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorizes appropriations to the Attorney General. SEC. 7. NATIONAL MEDAL OF VALOR OFFICE. The National Medal of Valor Office is established within the Department of Justice to support the Board in setting criteria for nominees and designing the Medal of Valor. SEC. 8. CONFORMING REPEAL. Section 15 of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to establish the Director's Award For Distinguished Public Safety Service. Subsections are reorganized and paragraphs are removed. SEC. 9. CONSULTATION REQUIREMENT. The Board must consult with the Institute of Heraldry within the Department of Defense on the design of the Medal of Valor. Suggestions from the Department of Justice and individuals not employed by the Department may also be considered. This is part of a bill to establish a national medal for public safety officers who demonstrate extraordinary valor.
